Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Stereotype Threat Among Adults with Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES-1030117
PI: Lynn Smith-Lovin
Co-PI: Steven Foy
Institution: Duke University

This project compares test-taking performance between adults with ADHD (Attention Deficit Hyper Activity Disorder) who are explicitly exposed to stereotype threat on the basis of their condition to adults with ADHD who have not been explicitly exposed to stereotype threat. Comparisons will be made with non-ADHD-affected persons to determine the difference, if one exists, between normative test anxiety and medicalization-based stereotype threat. The effect of a frequently-provided test-taking accommodation for persons with ADHD - extra time to complete the questions - will also be experimentally evaluated to determine the extent to which it might offset stereotype threat.

Broader Impacts:
If stereotype threat negatively impacts test-taking performance among persons with ADHD, this will provide evidence for one way in which the labeling component of medicalization may harm patients despite the possible benefits involved with having a diagnosis to which counter-normative behavior may be attributed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Stereotype threat occurs when people are aware of negative stereotypes about members of a group to which they belong, and they encounter a scenario in which they become concerned that they might confirm these stereotypes. Under conditions of stereotype threat, people often perform below their normal abilities. This project tested whether having ADHD and being exposed to ADHD-based stereotype threat can negatively impact performance on standardized test questions.  Since ADHD symptomatology includes potential challenges to test-taking, such as inattention and difficult focusing, it could be reasonably anticipated to invoke feelings of concern about confirming expectations of distraction from a given test being taken. Thus, stereotype threat could add a secondary impairment to test performance over and above the direct impairment already emanating from the symptomatology of ADHD itself.  Results from this study indicated that, in general, persons with ADHD achieved lower scores on both quantitative and qualitative GRE questions as compared with persons without ADHD. However, when stereotype threat was explicitly invoked in persons with ADHD on the basis of their diagnosis, their performance on quantitative GRE questions was lower on average than the performance of persons with ADHD not exposed to stereotype threat.  Testing agencies should consider these results in developing procedures to ensure that stereotype threat is not unfairly penalizing persons with documented mental illnesses in the testing process.
